questions.text: Match the following components of a nerve with their corresponding structures: 1. Endoneurium a. Surrounds nerve 2. Perineurium b. Surrounds axons 3. Epineurium c. Surrounds fascicles
questions.explanation:
1.Endoneurium

b. Surrounds axons

2. Perineurium

c. Surrounds fascicles

3. Epineurium

a. Surrounds nerve

Somatic nervous system

Autonomic nervous system

Voluntary control

Involuntary control

Skeletal muscle innervation

Smooth muscle, cardiac muscle and glands

One neuron from CNS to effector(motor)

Preganglionic and Postganglionic neurons

Divided into sensory and motor nerve

Divided into sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve

Controls voluntary movement of skeletal muscles.

Regulates involuntary movements such as heart rate, and digestion.

questions.text: What is the approximate rate of axon regeneration in the peripheral nervous system (PNS)?
questions.explanation:
Fractures and dislocations
  • Most common cause

Uncontrolled diabetes
  • 2nd Most common cause

Direct injury
  • Cut, laceration

Mechanical injury

Compression

  • Radial nerve - Saturday night palsy
  • Axillary nerve - Dislocation of the shoulder
 

Traction

  • Birth injury- Erb’s palsy

Ischaemic injury
  • Volkmann’s ischaemia

Toxic agents
  • Inj. Tetracycline results in radial nerve palsy.

Radiation
  • For cancer treatment

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the pathology of neuropraxia?

options.label: A
options.text: Complete interruption of both axons and surrounding structures

options.label: B
options.text: Disruption of the myelin sheath with preserved axon integrity

options.label: C
options.text: Degeneration of the axon with intact surrounding connective tissue

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of the entire nerve, including the surrounding connective tissues

questions.correct_answer: B. Disruption of the myelin sheath with preserved axon integrity
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Prognosis

Neurapraxia

(Grade I)
  • Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • No neuroma and no degeneration.
  • Recovery is complete within 6 weeks.

Axonotmesis

(Grade II)
  • Axonal damage, connective tissue intact.
  • Neuroma in continuity.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Recovery can take up to months
  • Complete recovery may not occur.
  • Motor march present

Neurotmesis

(Grade III)
  • Complete nerve disruption.
  • End or side neuroma.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Spontaneous recovery never occurs.
  • Repair is required (poor recovery)

Definition
  • Physiological disruption of conduction in nerve fibre with temporary loss of motor and sensory function without any structural damage to the nerve.

 

Cause

Commonly caused by compression, stretching, or blunt trauma to a nerve, often seen in sports injuries, falls, or prolonged pressure.

Mechanism

Involves disruption of the myelin sheath surrounding the nerve fibers, which leads to a temporary conduction block while preserving the axon’s structure.

Symptoms

Temporary numbness, weakness, or tingling in the affected area.

Decreased reflexes and muscle strength, but usually not complete paralysis.

Diagnosis

Based on clinical examination and patient history; electrodiagnostic tests (e.g., nerve conduction studies) may confirm the diagnosis.

Classification

Classified as a first-degree nerve injury, indicating the least severe type of nerve injury.

Prognosis

Typically good, with recovery occurring within 6 weeks.

Treatment

Generally conservative; may include rest, physical therapy, and avoiding activities that could further irritate the nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding axonotmesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Spontaneous recovery occurs within days or weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of conduction within an intact neural tube

options.label: D
options.text: Occurs due to segmental demyelination by mechanical pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. Loss of conduction within an intact neural tube
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Prognosis

Neurapraxia

(Grade I)
  • Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • Segmental demyelination due to mechanical pressure (Option D)
  • No neuroma and no degeneration.
  • Recovery is complete within days or weeks (Option A)

Axonotmesis

(Grade II)
  • Axonal damage, connective tissue intact.
  • Loss of conduction within an intact neural tube - Neuroma in continuity (Option C)
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Recovery may occur spontaneously or take many months.
  • Complete recovery may not occur.
  • Motor march (nerve re-innervates muscles from proximal to distal) present

Neurotmesis

(Grade III)
  • Complete nerve disruption (Option B)
  • End or side neuroma.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Spontaneous recovery never occurs.
  • Repair is required (poor recovery)
  • Function maybe adequate but never complete

Axonal Damage

The axon is disrupted, causing Wallerian degeneration distal to the site of injury.

Intact Connective Tissues

The epineurium and perineurium remain intact, which facilitates axonal regrowth.

Wallerian Degeneration

Occurs distal to the injury, involving degeneration of the axon and myelin sheath.

Regeneration

The nerve has the potential to regenerate because the pathway for axonal growth is preserved, typically at a rate of 1-3 mm per day.

Crush Injuries

This is a common mechanism leading to axonotmesis, where the nerve is compressed or crushed, causing axonal damage.

Motor and Sensory Deficits

Loss of motor function and sensation distal to the injury.

Absent Reflexes

Reflexes in the affected region are typically absent.

Conservative Management

In most cases, surgical intervention is not necessary. Recovery occurs as the axon regenerates.

Physical therapy.

Prognosis

Good prognosis for recovery since the structural framework of the nerve is preserved, allowing for regrowth and reconnection of the nerve fibers.

Recovery can take weeks to months.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man sustains a deep laceration to his forearm from a sharp object. On examination, he has complete loss of motor function and sensation in the hand, and reflexes are absent. Despite immobilization and physical therapy, no improvement is noted after several weeks. Which type of nerve injury has most likely occurred?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Prognosis

Neurapraxia

(Grade I)
  • Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • No neuroma and no degeneration.
  • Recovery is complete within 6 weeks.

Axonotmesis

(Grade II)
  • Axonal damage, connective tissue intact.
  • Neuroma in continuity.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Recovery may occur spontaneously or take many months.
  • Complete recovery may not occur

Neurotmesis

(Grade III)
  • Complete nerve disruption.
  • End or side neuroma.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Complete recovery never occurs

Key features
  • Complete Disruption: Both the axon and the nerve's supportive structures are completely severed.
  • Loss of Function: This leads to total loss of motor and sensory function in the region supplied by the affected nerve.
  • Wallerian Degeneration: The portion of the axon distal to the injury undergoes Wallerian degeneration, where the axon and myelin sheath break down.

Common Causes
  • Severe Trauma: Penetrating injuries such as cuts, gunshot wounds, or severe crush injuries are common causes.

Clinical Presentation
  • Complete Motor and Sensory Loss: There is no movement or sensation distal to the injury. Reflexes in the affected area are absent.
  • No Spontaneous Recovery: Unlike less severe nerve injuries, neurotmesis does not allow for spontaneous recovery because the nerve's structural continuity is disrupted.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical Examination
  • Electromyography (EMG) and Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS)
  • MRI or ultrasound

Treatment
  • Surgical Repair: Nerve ends are surgically reconnected, or nerve grafting is performed to bridge the gap between the severed ends. Tendon transfer procedures are also done.
  • Physical Therapy: Post-surgical therapy is crucial to maintain muscle tone and promote recovery once the nerve starts regenerating.

Prognosis

Without Surgical Repair:

  • The prognosis is poor, with no chance of functional recovery.
 

With Surgical Repair:

  • Recovery depends on the extent of the injury, the length of time between injury and surgery, and the success of the repair.
  • Even with surgery, full recovery may not be possible, especially in cases of long nerve gaps or severe trauma.

questions.text: Focal segmental demyelination of a nerve is classified under Neurapraxia in the Seddon classification. What is the grade of the nerve injury according to the Sunderland classification?
questions.explanation:
Sunderland classification

Seddon classification

Injury

Management

Grade I

(Option A)

Neurapraxia

Focal segmental demyelination

Spontaneous Recovery

Grade II

(Option B ruled out)

Axonotmesis

Damaged axon with intact endoneurium

Spontaneous Recovery

Grade III

(Option C ruled out)


 

Axonotmesis

Damaged axon and endoneurium with intact perineurium

Surgical intervention may be needed
Grade IV (option D ruled out ) Axonotmesis Only the epineurium is intact. The nerve trunk is still in continuity but internal damage is severe  the injured segment should be excised and the nerve repaired or grafted
Grade V Neurotemesis The nerve is divided  Nerve repairment

questions.text: Grade IV nerve injury according to Sunderland classification corresponds to which Seddon classification?
questions.explanation:
Sunderland classification

Seddon classification

Injury

Management

Grade IV

Axonotmesis

(Option A)

Damaged axon, endoneurium, and perineurium with intact epineurium

Surgery

Grade V

Neurotmesis

(Option B ruled out)

Complete nerve transection (disruption of myelin sheath, axon, endoneurium, perineurium, and epineurium)

Surgery

questions.text: Which of the following best describes external neurolysis?
questions.explanation:
Conservative Treatment
  • Required in all types of nerve injury
  • Aimed at preserving limb mobility during nerve recovery
  • Types:
  • Splintage of the Paralysed Limb
  • Preserve Joint Mobility
  • Skin and Nail Care
  • Physiotherapy
  • Pain Relief

Operative Treatment

Nerve Suture
  • Techniques include epineural, epi-perineural, perineural, and group fascicular repair.
  • Methods for achieving an end-to-end suture: Mobilization, joint positioning, nerve course alteration, stripping branches, and sacrificing unimportant branches.

Nerve Grafting
  • For gaps greater than 10 cm or when tension is likely at the suture line.
  • The sural nerve is used as a graft.

Neurolysis
  • External Neurolysis: Freeing nerve from surrounding scar tissue. (Option A)
  • Internal Neurolysis: Dissecting nerve sheath to relieve internal pressure. (Option B ruled out)

Reconstructive Surgery
  • When there’s no hope of nerve recovery
  • Usually after 18 months
  • Types:
    • Tendon transfers
    • Arthrodesis
    • Muscle transfer

questions.text: What is the location at which the radial nerve is getting injured in a Saturday night palsy?
questions.explanation:
Location

Causes of radial nerve injury

In the Axilla
  • Aneurysm of the axillary vessels
  • Crutch palsy

In the Shoulder
  • Proximal humeral fractures
  • Shoulder dislocation

In the Spiral Groove

(5 ‘S’)

(Option D)
  • Shaft fracture
  • Saturday night palsy
  • Syringe palsy
  • Surgical positions (Trendelenburg)
  • 'S’march's (Esmarch) tourniquet palsy

Between Spiral Groove and Lateral Epicondyle
  • Fracture shaft of humerus
  • Supracondylar fracture humerus
  • Lateral epicondyle fracture
  • Penetrating and gunshot injuries
  • Cubitus valgus deformity

At the Elbow
  • Posterior dislocation of the elbow
  • Fracture of the head of the radius
  • Monteggia fractures

In the Forearm
  • Fracture of both bones in the forearm
  • Penetrating and gunshot injuries

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy falls off the monkey bars, landing on his outstretched hand, and immediately experiences severe pain and swelling around his elbow. An X-ray reveals a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Which of the following features will not be seen if his radial nerve is injured?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of extension of metacarpophalangeal joints

questions.explanation:
Type

Injury

Clinical Features

Low Lesions

Fractures or dislocations at the elbow
  • Cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joints (Option A ruled out)
  • Thumb weakness (Option C ruled out)
  • Radial deviation of the wrist (Option B ruled out)

High Lesions

Humerus fractures or prolonged tourniquet pressure
  • Wrist drop
  • Inability to extend MCP joints or elevate thumb
  • Sensory loss around the anatomical snuffbox

Very High Lesions

Around the shoulder

  • Weakness of wrist and hand
  • Paralysis of triceps and absence of triceps reflex (Option D)

Type of Injury

Treatment

Open Injuries
  • Immediate exploration and nerve repair or grafting

Closed Injuries
  • Wait 12 weeks for recovery before exploring
  • Use EMG if no improvement; if denervation is detected, perform nerve exploration and repair or grafting

Fractures of Humerus
  • Assess for nerve injury on admission
  • If the injury appears post-manipulation or internal fixation, explore and repair or graft immediately

Recovery Management
  • Perform passive hand movements
  • Splint the wrist in extension-cock up splint:

  • Avoid ‘lively’ hand splints to prevent metacarpophalangeal joint contractures

Long-term Disability
  • Use tendon transfers: pronator teres to short radial extensor, flexor carpi radialis or ulnaris to finger extensors, palmaris longus to thumb abductor

questions.text: Following RTA, a young male presented with swelling over his elbow. X-ray revealed the following. Which of the following statements is true about the origin of the most likely nerve affected?
questions.explanation:
The course of ulnar nerve:

Muscles supplied:
  • Forearm: Flexor carpi ulnaris and medial ½ of flexor digitorum profundus
    • High ulnar paradox- In high lesions of the ulnar nerve (occur with elbow fractures or dislocations) the hand is not markedly deformed because the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus is paralyzed and the fingers are therefore less ‘clawed’
  • Hand: Palmaris brevis (superficial branch) and Adductor pollicis, Hypothenar muscles, Interossei and medial lumbricals (Deep branch).

Sensory supply: 

Causes of injury:
  • Axilla: Axillary artery aneurysm
  • Arm: Fracture shaft of humerus
  • Elbow: Supracondylar fracture humerus, Fracture - medial epicondyle and of humerus; cubitus valgus deformity causes tardy ulnar nerve palsy (slow onset)
  • Forearm: Fracture - shaft of radius/ulna
  • Wrist & Hand: Fracture - hook of hamate; ulnar artery aneurysm
  • The most common site of ulnar nerve entrapment is the cubital tunnel > Guyon’s canal

questions.text: All of the following are tests done to test the nerve shown in the image except
questions.explanation:
Test

Action & Muscle tested

Froment’s sign:

(Option A)
  • Action tested: Adduction of the thumb
  • Muscles: Palmar interossei, Adductor pollicis.
  • Compensation: In ulnar nerve injury, to hold the paper, the patient uses Flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) - which is responsible for the ‘P sign’ (or) ‘Froment sign’.

Card test:

(Option D)
  • Action tested: Adduction of fingers
  • Muscle: Palmar interossei

Egawa test:

(Option C)
  • Action tested: Abduction of fingers
  • Muscle: Dorsal interossei

questions.text: The patient presents to you with the following deformity as shown. Which is the ideal procedure of choice to correct this deformity?
questions.explanation:
Partial claw hand:
  • Clawing: Hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of interphalangeal joints.
  • Clawing is seen in 2 medial fingers only.
  • Seen in pure ulnar nerve injury.
  • Also known as the true claw hand.

Complete claw hand:
  • Clawing of all 4 fingers.
  • Seen in combined median + ulnar nerve palsy

Tardy ulnar nerve palsy:
  • Slow-onset (over years) ulnar nerve palsy.
  • Seen with cubitus valgus deformity seen in lateral epicondyle humerus fracture.

Other deformities:
  • Wasting of hypothenar muscles & intrinsic muscles of the hand.
  • Hollow inter-metacarpal spaces in hand.

Static procedure (removal)
  • Zancolli Lasso procedure

Dynamic procedures (tendon transfer)
  • Modified Bunnel technique
  • Brand’s operation
  • Fowler’s operation

questions.text: The child presented with swelling around the elbow joint following a fall over an outstretched hand. X-ray elbow AP & Lateral views are given below.  Which among the following is true regarding the most likely nerve injured in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Descends adjacent to radial artery in the forearm

options.label: C
options.text: Gives motor branches in the arm

options.label: D
options.text: Supplies lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus

questions.correct_answer: D. Supplies lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus
questions.explanation:
Course and anatomy:


 

Muscles supplied:
  • Arm: none (Option C)
  • Forearm:
    • All flexor muscles except Flexor carpi ulnaris and medial ½ of flexor digitorum profundus (supplied by ulnar nerve) (Option D)
  • Hand:
    • Thenar muscles: Abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis and flexor pollicis brevis
    • 1st and 2nd lumbricals (Option B)

Causes of injury:
  • Arm: Tight tourniquet (most common, causes neuropraxia), Humerus fracture
  • Elbow: Supracondylar fracture, Posterior dislocation of elbow.
  • Wrist: Carpal tunnel syndrome

questions.text: The clinician performed the following test as shown. Which muscle is being tested here?

options.label: D
options.text: Lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus

questions.explanation:
Test

Muscle tested and action

Pen test:
  • Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis (Option C)
  • Action: Abduction of thumb

Oschner clasp test:
  • Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus
  • Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits
  • Pointing index sign seen.

Thumb opposition:
  • Muscle: Opponens pollcis
  • Action: Opposition of thumb
  • O-sign is seen in normal patients

questions.text: A 40-year-old male following RTA presented with a deformity of the lower limb. The clinician prescribed him a splint as shown below. What is the likely site of injury in this patient based on the markings in this X-ray?
questions.explanation:
Anatomy:
  • The terminal branch of the sciatic nerve arises from the popliteal fossa.
  • Root value: L4,L5,S1 & S2.
  • Hooks around the neck of the fibula.
  • Terminates by dividing into Superficial peroneal nerve & Deep peroneal nerve

Muscles supplied:
  • Superficial peroneal nerve: Peroneus longus & brevis (foot eversion)
  • Deep peroneal nerve: Peroneus tertius, Tibialis anterior, Extensor digitorum, Extensor hallucis longus.

Cutaneous supply of foot:

Common peroneal nerve injury:

Causes
  • Most common: Neck of fibula fracture (Option D)
  • Posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Fracture lateral tibial condyle

Clinical features
  • Foot drop (inability to evert)
  • High stepping gait

Treatment
  • Conservative (mainstay): Foot drop splint

  • Surgical (tendon transfer) - only done >12 months of no recovery:
    • Barr’s technique
    • Ober’s technique
